entry.title: Objective-C: How Brad Cox‚Äôs programming language has shaped Sketch since day one
entry.summary: After the passing of Objective-C‚Äôs creator, we reflect on how instrumental it has been for our company and our industry
entry.content:
We often use this blog to talk about new Sketch features, or pull back the curtain on how we work here ‚Äî such as exploring our creative process, or looking into how we optimize the Mac app. But one thing I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve ever really talked about is our programming language.

Today, though, as we reflect on the recent passing of Objective-C‚Äôs co-creator Dr Brad Cox Ph.D., we have a good reason to do just that.

Objective-C was first adopted by NeXT, and later became the foundation of Mac OS X (now known as macOS). It was the best way to write Mac apps ‚Äî¬†and for the first eight years or so of Sketch, we wrote almost all the app‚Äôs code with it. Most of that code is still there.

A programming language really forms the lowest building blocks of an app, and shapes how developers interact with the machine. It has a foundational impact on what‚Äôs possible, and therefore directly affects the final product ‚Äî¬†far more than an end-user could ever know.

Dr Cox and his business partner, Tom Love, built Objective-C on top of the old industry foundation of C, and the result was a powerful and very dynamic language. Its infamous quirk ‚Äî¬†the ‚Äòweird‚Äô square-bracket syntax it used for its functions ‚Äî puzzled many an early developer. But once you got past that, you got the high speed and low memory footprint of regular C code, with a thin but flexible Object-Oriented layer on top.

It was certainly a big step up from Java and Swing, which I learnt at University. I would simply describe it as ‚Äòelegant‚Äô ‚Äî something I‚Äôd never say of those two languages. Despite the Mac‚Äôs small market share at the time, that elegance got me hooked. I was instilled with a desire to create apps that were like Apple‚Äôs ‚Äî and like those made by the other indies out there that I respected tremendously.

The influence of Objective-C can hardly be understated. I think it‚Äôs fair to say that there would‚Äôve been no iPhone without Objective-C. It‚Äôs certainly true that AppKit ‚Äî NeXT‚Äôs and later Apple‚Äôs original UI framework ‚Äî was built for Objective-C. The language and the frameworks were beautiful, and a joy to work with. They‚Äôre a bit long in the tooth now, but they‚Äôre still going strong more than 30 years on, and that is in no small part thanks to the language they were all built on. That‚Äôs one hell of a legacy to leave behind, and we at Sketch are eternally grateful for it.

If you want to read more about Objective-C‚Äôs origins, check out Masterminds of Programming by Federico Biancuzzi, or take some time to read John Gruber‚Äôs recent musings on its impact.

entry.title: Keeping it real: How Nikola Lazarevic creates photorealistic objects in Sketch
entry.summary: We discover the skills, tips and tricks it takes to make realistic digital objects in Sketch
entry.content:
We love seeing what you make with Sketch ‚Äî you truly create some incredible work with our humble Mac app. And every now and then a project comes along that blows our collective minds. So when we saw what appeared to be a photograph of a Porsche 911 with the #MadeWithSketch hashtag, we had to know more.

We sat down with Nikola Lazarevic, a visual designer for web and print at Simplicity LLC, a small design and development agency from Ni≈° in Serbia, to find out how he created that ‚Äî and many other photorealistic images ‚Äî¬†in Sketch.

What‚Äôs your background in design? Have you always enjoyed recreating real items digitally?

I‚Äôm a self-taught designer with a Master‚Äôs degree in Computer Science. I started working as a designer back in 2008.

I‚Äôve always had a weird passion for recreating real items in digital form. It all started with wristwatches that I admire in terms of aesthetics and function. These are watches I would love to own, but could never afford. From there I‚Äôve expanded my work to vintage supercars, like Porsches, Alfa Romeos, Lamborghinis and Ferraris. I‚Äôve also recreated timeless objects designed by Dieter Rams, Dietrich Lubs and Mario Bellini, just to name a few. I find it fun and it helps me to relax between tasks in my daily work!

It‚Äôs fair to say that Sketch isn‚Äôt always the first app designers think of for recreating photo-realistic objects. Why do you enjoy working in Sketch for these projects?

Well, I guess using Sketch is a bit of an unusual choice! I used to use Photoshop, which is a more typical choice, but drawing with a Pen Tool is challenging and time-consuming ‚Äî and Photoshop always felt too complicated and massive.

Five years ago I discovered Sketch and I‚Äôve never looked back. Since then I‚Äôve been using it daily for all kinds of work ‚Äî from UI and poster design, to brochure design, photorealistic drawing and more.

In that time I‚Äôve learned to use the vector tool in Sketch quite well. I love how easy it is to control and switch between different types of vector points. I like the option to apply multiple colors and shadow effects to a shape. Symbols are such a powerful feature and time-saver. And the infinite canvas is great. Quite often, when I draw a car I start directly on the Canvas without an actual Artboard, because for me the Canvas is kind of an Artboard too ‚Äî just without actual dimensions. I also love the ability to export finished work in different sizes with just a few clicks.

The bottom line is ‚Äî in Sketch everything feels so easy and natural. It‚Äôs not packed with unnecessary features, it‚Äôs very fast, and because everything is vector based, it‚Äôs all infinitely scalable. So I don‚Äôt have to worry about possible resolution issues.

So I decided to give it a go and try Sketch for photorealistic illustrations of real objects. And as you can see, it can be done ‚Äî it‚Äôs really fun and I‚Äôm enjoying it very much.

The bottom line is ‚Äî in Sketch everything feels so easy and natural. It‚Äôs not packed with unnecessary features, it‚Äôs very fast, and because everything is vector based, it‚Äôs all infinitely scalable. So I don‚Äôt have to worry about possible resolution issues.

Doing this type of work in Sketch also helps you sharpen your skills and learn more about the software itself, its functions, and its possibilities.

What tricks have you learned over the years when it comes to making things look ‚Äòreal‚Äô in Sketch?

I think the most important thing is the proper use of light and textures. You won‚Äôt believe what can be achieved using Gradients, Shadows, Inner Shadows, and Gaussian Blur¬†‚Äî they all help make an object look real.

Lighting and shadows add depth and make illustrations pop and feel more realistic. It‚Äôs also quite important to choose a single-point light source ‚Äî it makes it easier to understand where to put highlights and shadows.

I use gradients to establish lighting ‚Äî lighter colors in the gradient show where the light is coming from. Then I create flat shapes for highlights and shadows based on the light‚Äôs direction. In the end, I use Gaussian blur to soften them and achieve a more realistic look. The bigger the gap between the brightest highlight and darkest shadow, the more 3D and realistic your object looks. But if you overdo it, details will get lost.

Also, you can use Pattern Fill on its own ‚Äî or combine it with Motion Blur ‚Äî to create textures like plastic, brushed metal, and more, which adds a nice realistic touch to illustration.

How long does a design typically take you?

When I started I was really slow. I needed a couple of days to finish a car or a watch. Over time I‚Äôve become much faster. With every illustration, I‚Äôve learned more about Sketch‚Äôs functions and features, which has helped me speed up.

How long a project takes me depends on the complexity of the object, but nowadays I can finish a watch under four hours, or a car in 15-16 hours. Practice is everything. The more time you spend learning about the software you use the more efficient you become.

What‚Äôs your design process for a project like this?

I always start with real-life photography on the Canvas, since I draw objects that already exist.

The design process is quite simple: I choose an object that I want to draw ‚Äî¬†a car, watch, radio, or any other object¬†‚Äî and I try to find as many photos of it from different angles so I can carefully replicate all of the important details. The devil is in these details ‚Äî they make all the difference, and make your illustration stand out from the crowd.

I also like to learn the historical background about an object I draw. Somehow it helps me get into the mood.

How does Sketch help you when it comes to creating these designs? Which tools do you use the most?

It all starts with the Vector tool that I use to outline all the elements.

Then I style every element using solid colors, different types of gradients, inner shadows, and shadows.

I quite often use the Rotate Copies function, which is a real time-saver ‚Äî imagine manually rotating 300 lines around a circle! ‚Äî as well as Boolean operations to create complex shapes. And I use Symbols a lot. It‚Äôs a powerful Sketch feature and yet another time-saver, since I often have reusable elements in my illustrations.

What tips and advice do you have for other designers looking to start creating more realistic work in Sketch?

Start with simple objects. Then with every new illustration you create, move towards more and more complex objects. It‚Äôs also important to pay attention to the small details, because they make the biggest difference. Spending time on these will make your illustration more impressive and realistic.

You also must arm yourself with patience. Designing realistic objects is not an easy task, but the end result will be well worth it. And finally, no matter how frustrating this type of work can be sometimes ‚Äî don‚Äôt forget to smile. üòä

We love sharing your design projects and telling your stories. If you‚Äôve recently had a project that you‚Äôve #MadeWithSketch, let us know on our social channels so we can share it with the rest of our community.

entry.title: Building better: How Sketch helps Salesforce maintain its industry-leading design system
entry.summary: We talk Assistants and designing at scale with the Salesforce team to discover the key to a great design system
entry.content:
A good design system makes everyone‚Äôs life easier. It gives designers the elements and guidance they need to work within an approved structure. It helps developers work with predictable, consistent components. And it helps businesses design and build new products, faster ‚Äî¬†all with consistent user experiences.

And if you know design systems, you probably know Salesforce. Salesforce‚Äôs Lightning Design System is an industry leader, with thousands of components, clear instructions, and sensible, considered decisions about color and sizing. Plus, it comes with a Sketch Library, so it‚Äôs super simple to pick up and use.

The Lightning Design System has evolved a great deal since its launch in 2015, but after speaking to Kirupa Chinnathambi, Senior Director of PM on the system, it‚Äôs clear that the core goals remain the same today. ‚ÄúAs Stephanie Rewis, one of the founding engineers of the Lightning Design System describes, the initial goals were around providing a scalable and maintainable way for teams to adopt the latest evolution of our UX guidance,‚Äù he says. For the team, that means great documentation, plenty of visual assets, strong communication channels and feedback loops across the ecosystem, and much more.

‚ÄúToday, we take these two goals and their outputs for granted,‚Äù Kirupa continues. ‚ÄúBut when the Lightning Design System was first coming online, the team was really paving new ground with little prior art to reference.‚Äù Today, the team is constantly evolving what the Lightning Design System does ‚Äî¬†and basing that evolution on research, customer feedback, telemetry and industry trends. But those original two goals are never far from the forefront.

But there‚Äôs another key aspect that makes the Lightning Design System such a huge success ‚Äî one that is more about people than design.

Making it personal

‚ÄúOne of the biggest aspects for us is having good relationships with the teams that use our design system to build their UX,‚Äù says Kirupa. With the Lightning Design System, that‚Äôs everyone from internal teams at Salesforce that are evolving the company‚Äôs various products, to external designers and developers who use the platform for their own solutions.

‚ÄúOne of the biggest aspects for us is having good relationships with the teams that use our design system to build their UX‚Äù

‚ÄúKeeping in close communication ‚Äî directly and indirectly¬†‚Äî across our vast ecosystem is a time-consuming task. But it‚Äôs also really rewarding, because it ensures we spend our time building the right things.‚Äù

And those relationships have another valuable benefit for the team, too‚Äî providing behind-the-scenes glimpse at how the roles of design and engineering are constantly evolving. ‚ÄúWe get a more accurate, dotted-line roadmap that we can be creative in filling out,‚Äù Kirupa explains. ‚ÄúOur investments in design and developer tools, which are fairly unique for a design system team, is one example of how we react to these insights in a targeted way.‚Äù

For Salesforce, those tools include a powerful Sketch plugin, dedicated UI design kits and, most recently, a new Assistant ‚Äî¬†the Lightning Design System Linter.

Rules are made to be followed

When we released Assistants with Sketch 68, we wanted to help you spot issues with your documents, stay consistent with design systems and prepare your files for collaboration. For Salesforce, creating an Assistant that helped users follow the Lightning Design System rules was a no-brainer.

‚ÄúKeeping in communication across our vast ecosystem is time-consuming. But it‚Äôs also really rewarding, because it ensures we spend our time building the right things.‚Äù

‚ÄúDefining rules for using the system is hugely important ‚Äî both on the design and engineering side,‚Äù¬†says John Earle, Lead Software Engineer on the Lightning Design System. But for the Salesforce team, it‚Äôs just as important to make those rules easy to follow.

‚ÄúWith a system as expansive as the Lightning Design System, it‚Äôs easy for even seasoned Salesforce designers to use color values or text sizes that don‚Äôt correspond to tokens,‚Äù he continues. These small errors have a cascading effect, resulting in hardcoded values in code. And because it‚Äôs hard to change those later on, it makes the end user‚Äôs experience inconsistent.

Using the Lightning Design System Linter with a Sketch document is simple. Once you‚Äôve added it, it‚Äôll run in the background, showing notifications if there are any aspects of your design that don‚Äôt follow the Lightning Design Systems‚Äôs rules.

‚ÄúKeeping users informed of these rules ‚Äî¬†and making sure they‚Äôre enforced ‚Äî is just as important as the rules themselves,‚Äù continues John. ‚ÄúMost of our rules live directly within the system, in metadata. An API disseminates these rules, which is why we can build and use enforcement tools, such as our SLDS Validator, and now, the Lightning Design System Linter.‚Äù

Part of the family

When combined with the Lightning Design System‚Äôs Sketch plugin, the Sketch UI kit, and the fonts, colors and icons that Salesforce offers, it‚Äôs a seriously powerful combination. Not only do you have all the components and assets you need to design, you have information on how to use it correctly ‚Äî¬†and an Assistant to tell you if you make a mistake.

‚ÄúThe audience for our design system spans all skill levels ‚Äî from designers, developers and product managers to admins and ‚Äòaccidental‚Äô designers for whom the designer hat is just one of the many hats they already wear,‚Äù¬†says Kirupa. ‚ÄúThe most rewarding part is seeing our customers across all these diverse skillsets use the guidance, tools, and out-of-the-box solutions we provide to bring their own user experiences to life.‚Äù

For users, this all means that it doesn‚Äôt matter if you spend all your time in Sketch:

Or if you like to write code:

However you work, the Lightning Design System can help you ‚Äî to borrow from the company‚Äôs mission statement ‚Äî build beautiful, performant, and accessible product experiences. And now, that‚Äôs all backed up by a powerful Assistant.

Assistant simplicity

Before we let the Salesforce team go, we wanted to ask about their experience of building their Lightning Design System Linter. Our team designed Assistants to be easy-to-create ‚Äî¬†did their hard work pay off?

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had a blast building our Assistant!‚Äù smiles John. ‚ÄúSetup was quick ‚Äî I had my first rule up and running in minutes. I love that the context object gives me easy access to document properties, so I don‚Äôt need to crawl through layers to find what I need. The Typescript environment helps me adhere to the proper interface, and guides me with autocomplete in VS Code. And to top it all off, I can have Jest watch for changes as I‚Äôm developing so I don‚Äôt need to recompile my code manually. The development experience is well-documented and modern ‚Äî a pleasure to work in.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had a blast building our Assistant! The development experience is well-documented and modern ‚Äî a pleasure to work in.‚Äù

It‚Äôs great to hear this kind of feedback from a team as big and successful as Salesforce. But this isn‚Äôt the end of their plans for design validation in Sketch. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve really just scratched the surface with our initial release of the Assistant,‚Äù says John. ‚ÄúIn the future we‚Äôre looking to validate spacing between and within layers. And we‚Äôd like to connect the Assistant to our Lightning Design System Plugin to generate specifications for engineers. These specs will reference design system token values and component blueprints, so engineers don‚Äôt need to go out of their way to find what they need to use.‚Äù

Looking ahead

Beyond its Assistant, the future is bright for Salesforce. And while Kirupa can‚Äôt talk too much about their plans, he does share a few little tidbits. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll continue to invest in the big areas we‚Äôve been actively talking about over the past year, including guidance and documentation, tooling support, richer component styling (via Styling Hooks), accessibility support (including WCAG 2.0 and 2.1), mobile-friendly enhancements, an improved color system, and much more.‚Äù

But for Kirupa, what‚Äôs more exciting than any of these future plans is seeing how people use the Lightning Design System to create amazing work. Sometimes, they go far beyond what the team could ever have planned. ‚ÄúMy favorite cool story is when someone dropped by our booth at Dreamforce and explained how they are using the design system to help build a Virtual Reality experience for navigating through their data,‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúI often wonder if they were from the future!‚Äù

entry.title: The new Sketch icon: how we redesigned a classic for Big Sur
entry.summary: ‚ÄúWe tried to explore as many ideas as possible to see what we could do with the new style‚Äù
entry.content:
Last month we released version 70 of our Mac app with a major UI refresh for macOS Big Sur. And while our design team spent a long time working out the best way to get Sketch looking great in the updated OS, they had another project to think about ‚Äî a new icon for the Mac app.

The UI needed hundreds of hours of work to get pixel-perfect, but redesigning an icon that may sit in your Dock (and in front of your eyes) all day, every day is no small task either.

This week we sat down with the project‚Äôs Design Lead, Prekesh, to find out how he went about re-imagining the Sketch icon for a new era, and why it was never as simple as just recreating our famous diamond.

Experimentation

Reimagining an icon that‚Äôs so well-known across the industry is no easy challenge. For Prekesh, the goal was to try and do something new, while maintaining the essence of Sketch.

‚ÄúI think I called the first document I created ‚Äòdefinitely not a diamond on a white box‚Äò,‚Äù he says, with a wry smile. ‚ÄúWe tried to explore as many ideas and options as possible to see what we could do with Big Sur‚Äôs new style.‚Äù He isn‚Äôt kidding. The process started with almost 50 concepts on an iPad, drawn using an Apple Pencil.

‚ÄúI just started sketching a bunch of ideas that came to my mind, no matter how outlandish,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúThe goal was to throw ideas at the wall and see what stuck, what didn‚Äôt, and what we could move forward with.‚Äù Next, he took those drawings into Sketch and started exploring the different approaches in higher fidelity.

As he posted updates in our internal Slack channels, excitement started to grow, and he got a ton of useful feedback from other designers on the team. Some of the more ‚Äòout there‚Äô designs really picked up some interest, as Prekesh thought about the pros and cons of reinventing the app‚Äôs icon entirely.

‚ÄúWe experimented with moving away from the diamond, but that seemed a little silly considering that it‚Äôs such a strong part of our brand,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúSo we created a bunch of new diamond shapes ‚Äî some with perspective, some without; some with more faces, some with less.‚Äù From there, it became of question of which ones worked best, and how to integrate these elements with different backdrops.

Finding the balance

Getting the balance right between the foreground shapes and the background was particularly tough. ‚ÄúSomething we found out very quickly was that there was often a visual struggle between the rounded rectangle backdrop and the diamond,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe knew we needed to find a way for them to compliment each other, rather than fight for the viewers‚Äô attention.‚Äù

As work progressed, two frontrunners emerged, both on a similar background ‚Äî one using something very close to our current diamond, and another that took a more 3D approach.

In the end, after several weeks of internal testing and a lot of input from teams across the company, the decision was clear. This would be our final icon:

It‚Äôs all in the details

For Prekesh, it‚Äôs the small details that make our new icon special. ‚ÄúI like its subtlety,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThere are details and iterations that update the previous icon, but don‚Äôt necessarily move too far away from what makes the Sketch icon the Sketch icon.‚Äù But after all his outlandish sketches, is he disappointed that we ended up with a design that‚Äôll feel familiar to people?

‚ÄúNot really ‚Äî that‚Äôs kind of what felt right to go with after all of our explorations,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúAnd there are some subtle details that I love. The rounded rectangle background is actually a simplified representation of Sketch‚Äôs Big Sur user interface, and the Sidebar on the left has transparency, which means it ever-so-slightly takes on the background color of your wallpaper.‚Äù The diamond itself got some love too ‚Äî Prekesh redrew and re-colored it from scratch to improve the contrast and make it slightly more vibrant. Plus, a new, deeper shadow makes it feel like it‚Äôs really floating in front of the UI.

Prekesh says he took his inspiration from Big Sur‚Äôs new design, and Apple‚Äôs own icons ‚Äî of which he‚Äôs a big fan. ‚ÄúI love the new direction,‚Äú he says. ‚ÄúThe restriction of the rounded rectangle for icons will no doubt encourage people to use that space more creatively.‚Äù

Reflecting on the process of reinventing such a well-known icon, Prekesh admits he felt the huge responsibility on his shoulders. ‚ÄúIt was a little surreal at first, because I‚Äôve looked up to the designers of the previous icons for basically my entire career,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúFor Emanuel (S√°, our Chief Design Officer) and Marcelo (Marfil, our Design Director) to entrust me to explore and create the next iteration of the app icon felt pretty great. But the pressure was on!‚Äù he laughs.

The Sketch Cinematic Universe

As if redesigning the icon you‚Äôll see in your Dock every day wasn‚Äôt enough of the challenge, that wasn‚Äôt the end of the journey. As well as the version of our Mac app that you use, we also maintain several test builds, each at a different stage of development. From the QA team‚Äôs Debug version and the early Experimental build, all the way through to our Private and Public Beta versions, we use different icons for each so it‚Äôs clear who‚Äôs testing what features, and when.

Before, we simply used different colored diamonds to denote the different versions. But for Big Sur, Prekesh decided to have some fun. ‚ÄúI thought of ideas where there was literal visual progress from the ‚ÄòXcode build‚Äô icon all the way to public release icon, and they sort of told a story,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúBut that would only make sense to us internally, and didn‚Äôt feel like the right approach for these.‚Äù

The result is six completely unique icons, each with its own color scheme and flavor. It was a chance for Prekesh to bring some of those early, more outlandish ideas to life.

‚ÄúOur Experimental build always includes the newest features that we‚Äôre working on, and Glenn [Hitchcock, another member of the design team] had the idea to try something that showed that it was really ‚Äòout there‚Äô. So why not put the diamond in space?‚Äù

And what about the icon hiding behind the curtain? ‚ÄúThat one‚Äôs slightly funny. We wanted to tease the new icon on Twitter, so I spent most of a day drawing the cloth for what was just going to be used in a teaser image,‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúAfter all that work, I realized we could actually use it for our Private Beta icon. So that saved me some time!‚Äù

For Prekesh, the challenge was to give each icon its own identity ‚Äî and make sure it communicated something about what people should expect from that version. He‚Äôs pleased with the results. And it‚Äôs fair to say they‚Äôve gone down well with the rest of the team internally, too.

‚ÄúI suspect some people will see these and want to use them as their main Sketch icon,‚Äù he smiles. ‚ÄúHey, all I can say is: we‚Äôre hiring ‚Äî come join us!‚Äù

We love giving you behind-the-scenes peeks at the work we do on Sketch. What would you like to see? Let us know on social and we‚Äôll consider your ideas for our next sneak peek. For now, we hope you enjoy using the latest Mac release.

entry.title: Switching Silicon: How Sketch performs on Apple‚Äôs new hardware
entry.summary: Just how much faster is Sketch with Apple Silicon? We ran some tests ‚Äî and the results were impressive
entry.content:
Earlier this month, Apple finally announced its new M1 chip, and gave us some mind-blowing numbers to demonstrate how fast its three new Macs really are. Naturally, we were excited to get our hands on a new machine to test these performance claims for ourselves ‚Äî and see just how Sketch would run on this new hardware.

Measuring performance objectively across machines in an application as interactive as Sketch isn‚Äôt easy. Recording side-by-side operations produced some notable differences ‚Äî browsing through complicated Sketch documents was at least 40% faster in our measurements, for example ‚Äî and in an unscientific way everything felt faster. But we could never be sure whether other factors were at play.

But then we realized that we had another way to put the new Macs through their paces ‚Äî a more objective, measurable way.

A Mac mini server farm

At Sketch, the Mac mini holds a special place in our heart. We operate a server farm of 19 Mac minis. Together, they process over 60,000 Sketch documents every day ‚Äî for developer handoff, asset exporting, web previews, and our upcoming live collaboration feature. And as you can imagine, speed and performance make a huge difference here.

We wanted to know if the M1 chip would speed up our operations and ultimately make the experience of using Sketch even better as a result. To help us figure that out, we conducted three separate tests.

Measuring overall performance

First, let‚Äôs set the scene. For this test, we ordered the entry-level 2020 Mac mini, featuring an Apple M1 Chip with 8GB of RAM. Its purchase price is $699.

We‚Äôre comparing this machine with those that are currently running our render farm; the 2018 Mac mini, with 3.2 GHz Intel Core i7 processors and 32GB RAM. You can still buy this model today, starting at $1,299 for the same processor and 8GB RAM1.

To test performance, we took a number of complex Sketch documents, loaded them up, then exported a few hundred images out of each document2. This gives us a nice variety of ‚Äòdisk‚Äô activity, memory usage, CPU usage and GPU usage to help us compare the machines.

And how did they compare?

The results were impressive and confirmed our less scientific observations from earlier. The Mac minis currently running our render farm are the top-of-the-line model from 2018, and they were consistently outperformed by 30-40% in our first test compared to the base-line model of the new Mac mini. That‚Äôs 30-40% more performance for almost half the price!

It‚Äôs worth noting that these tests don‚Äôt accurately reflect interactive real-life Sketch use (due to all the disk writing, for example), nor are they designed to test one isolated unit on the chip ‚Äî like the CPU.

Measuring raw CPU

With that in mind, we decided to run another set of tests to get a better idea of how these two pieces of hardware perform from a raw CPU perspective. In this case we compared the results of a detach operation ‚Äî we took those same large and complex Sketch files and recursively detached every Symbol instance in each.

Performing this task gave us a better idea of how these two machines compare based almost solely on CPU. And what did we find?

Here, the results are almost identical with the lofty numbers we got from Apple. The new M1 Mac mini was almost twice as fast as our 2018 machine.

Comparing Apples to Apples

In the November event, Apple‚Äôs Laura Metz, Mac Product Line Manager, said that the MacBook Air is the world‚Äôs best-selling 13-inch notebook, and the company‚Äôs best-selling model. So we decided to test against an early 2020 Intel MacBook Air as well (1.1 GHz Intel Core i5 with 8 GB RAM). The Mac mini we‚Äôre testing here shares the same M1 chip as the newly released MacBook Air, so although it‚Äôs not a perfect comparison, it should be a decent indicator of the performance jump you can expect from the new Air compared to the older model.

And, just for good measure, we decided to throw in a 2019 16-inch MacBook Pro (2.3 GHz Intel Core i9 with 32GB RAM) as well. Because, why not?3

Again, the results are staggering. The 2019 MacBook Pro, as could be expected, easily outpaces the MacBook Air. But then our new Mac mini goes a step further, blowing both of them out of the water. The new Mac mini consistently completed these tasks three times faster than the early 2020 MacBook Air, and twice as fast as the 2019 MacBook Pro.

What it all means

There‚Äôs no doubt about it ‚Äî these M1 chips are truly amazing. It‚Äôs hard to put into words just how much more performance you get from this new generation of Macs compared to even their recent predecessors. Though, these numbers sure help quantify it.

For now, we‚Äôre eagerly waiting for Apple to have enough M1 Mac minis available for us to upgrade our server rendering operations. These new machines will help us process documents faster, run Cloud more efficiently, and make our exciting upcoming features better than ever.

The best news is that, as a Sketch user, you don‚Äôt have to buy a new Mac to feel the benefits of Apple‚Äôs M1 chip. We can deliver those improvements by upgrading our servers. And of course, if you are lucky enough to have a new M1 machine, we‚Äôve made sure our Mac app can take advantage of these big performance improvements ‚Äî so you can create amazing work, faster than ever.

  1. This $1,299 model only includes 8GB of RAM ‚Äî to upgrade to the 32GB RAM model we use in our server farms would cost $1,899. But the tests we‚Äôre carrying out here don‚Äôt get close to using that much RAM, so we didn‚Äôt think it was fair to compare those machines (and prices) specifically.¬†↩

  2. When using Sketch in real-life, we try to utilize all cores efficiently. In this setup, the workflow is deliberately single-threaded so we can run a lot of these processes together efficiently. Remember, this is not a typical workflow for users ‚Äî but it is a good reflection of the work we need to do on the server.¬†↩

  3. The Mac mini we tested has the same chip and speed as the latest M1 MacBook Air ‚Äî the mini simply has a fan to help heat dissipation. However, these tests wouldn‚Äôt cause CPU throttling to kick in had we measured this on an Air.¬†↩

entry.title: Yes Sur: Behind the scenes of Sketch‚Äôs macOS makeover
entry.summary: ‚ÄúWe always want to put your designs front and center so they can shine ‚Äî¬†the last thing we want is for the interface to get in the way.‚Äù
entry.content:
Today, we‚Äôre excited to share some details of our Big Sur update. Refreshing our UI for Apple‚Äôs latest OS has taken countless hours of hard work, tough decisions and careful revisions from dozens of people across the Sketch team. We want to say a big thank you to them all ‚Äî we‚Äôre incredibly proud of the work they‚Äôve done.

To get the lowdown on how the team created Sketch‚Äôs beautiful new interface ‚Äî and to show off some of our favorite details ‚Äî we sat down to chat with our Design Director Marcelo Marfil.

So what‚Äôs new?

‚ÄúEarly on, we had a single goal in mind. We wanted to make sure Sketch on Big Sur still put your designs front and center so they could shine,‚Äù Marcelo explains. ‚ÄúThe last thing we wanted was for the interface to get in the way.‚Äù With that in mind, the team focused on tweaking and refining the existing interface rather than a complete overhaul. They wanted the app to feel familiar after your Big Sur upgrade, so you could instantly get back into your designs. ‚ÄúIn essence, it continues to be the same Sketch people know and love,‚Äù he says. This is an evolution, not a revolution.

That said, the team did take the opportunity to push things a little further in a few key areas. ‚ÄúAdopting new OS standards like a full-height sidebar and toolbar already make a huge difference, but we couldn‚Äôt stop there,‚Äù says Marcelo.

Yes Sur

‚ÄúAs with anything new, there‚Äôs an inevitable learning curve you have to work through,‚Äù he continues. After taking some time to use the betas and understand the new paradigms, the team started exploring how they could make sure our native app still felt ‚Äòat home‚Äô on Mac ‚Äî while continuing to support people that want to stick with macOS Catalina (or even earlier OSs).

It started with the toolbar. While aligning with Apple‚Äôs new design, which adds the document title inline with other toolbar items, they reorganized the default toolbar with the tools they think you‚Äôll use the most. There‚Äôs even a new Notifications icon in the top-right corner of the window which gathers your notifications together, making them easy to manage. Don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî you can still customize it with your own favorite tools with a Ctrl-click. You‚Äôll also notice the toolbar (and the rest of the app) features some gorgeous new icons. More on them later.

Next, the team turned their attention to the Inspector. ‚ÄúEven though our app‚Äôs user interface feels at home on macOS, we rely a lot on custom controls and materials,‚Äù Marcelo explains. ‚ÄúIt always comes down to whether we think we can give our customers a better experience.‚Äù Like the rest of the Mac app, the new Inspector will feel familiar, but every element has been painstakingly reworked to be as beautiful as it is functional.

You‚Äôll also notice that the accent color across the app has changed ‚Äî it‚Äôs now orange, to match our brand colors across the Sketch platform. Of course, if orange isn‚Äôt your thing, you can choose a color you like in System Preferences. ‚ÄúAnd we modernized our Documents Window,‚Äù Marcelo points out. ‚ÄúIt now has a much more familiar look.‚Äù

Evolution, not revolution

‚ÄúWhen Apple rolled out the first few betas, we took our time and went deep into OS changes and paradigms.‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúWe wanted to better understand what would work for us, and where we could do better.‚Äù

As a result of that thinking, you‚Äòll find that some tools, such as Scale, have changed from Sheets to become modes in the Inspector. Big Sur‚Äôs new, larger design for Sheets would have covered the Canvas while you made adjustments. By shifting them to the Inspector, you can carry on working uninterrupted.

‚ÄúAs we always try to do at Sketch, I believe we found a good balance between what the system has to offer and where we want to take it to going forward,‚Äù says Marcelo. And never was this balance more apparent than in the team‚Äôs approach to new icons.

Iconic design

The introduction of SF Symbols in Big Sur brings together iOS and Mac iconography to make it consistent for the first time. Unfortunately, Apple Symbols simply didn‚Äôt offer the design team enough control when it came to implementing icons across the interface.

‚ÄúAt Sketch we care deeply about our iconography and pixel precision,‚Äù says Marcelo. ‚ÄúEven though Apple Symbols is a great concept, sadly it didn‚Äôt quite live up to our standards.‚Äù Because Apple designed SF Symbols to support multiple weights and sizes, their edges can sometimes appear slightly blurred. After a lot of discussion, the team decided that Apple‚Äôs Symbols weren‚Äôt right for the first Sketch release on Big Sur. Instead, they reworked every icon as a vector.

‚ÄùWe wanted to make sure our new icons had a good balance of crispness and smoothness, but still fit nicely within the Big Sur theme and our brand,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúAfter all, we make a design app for designers.‚Äù We know we‚Äôre biased, but we hope you‚Äôll agree that the results are quite beautiful.

This isn‚Äôt the end for icon design in our Mac app, though. As with all aspects of our Big Sur design, the team are keeping an eye on developments for future releases. ‚ÄúI honestly hope we can eventually convert our own icons to Apple‚Äôs Symbols too, with all their sizes and suitable weight variants.‚Äù

This is just the start

This might be a new design for Sketch, but as Marcelo explains, our philosophy remains the same. ‚ÄúEven with a fresh new look, this update is a continuation of everything we learned over the last decade,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúOur focus has always been on giving you the tools you need to create amazing designs in a native Mac application. We couldn‚Äôt be more excited to be part of this important milestone for the Mac ecosystem.‚Äù And as Marcelo is keen to stress, this is just the start. Sketch will continue to evolve, just like Apple‚Äôs new design language.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to take this moment to thank everyone involved internally in this redesign,‚Äù he concludes, reflecting on the process. ‚ÄúIt was quite a challenge but I couldn‚Äôt be more proud of what our team achieved in such a short time.‚Äù

Sketch 70 is available now. You can get the update, read our release notes, check out our documentation, or just spend the next few hours gazing lovingly at those icons, which is what we‚Äôve been doing for the last month or so. Let us know what you think of our redesign on social ‚Äî we‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts.

entry.title: Comment threads, Color Variables support, and a safety net for deleted documents ‚Äî What's new in Cloud?
entry.summary: Introducing a small set of Cloud updates that add up to even better collaboration in the browser
entry.content:
This year, we‚Äôve been working hard to make Cloud an incredible place to collaborate. We kicked off by launching Cloud Inspector in January and individual asset exports in June, bringing free developer handoff in the browser to anyone, on any operating system. We‚Äôve also been doing a lot of underlying work, including a major database upgrade, that paves the way for some exciting future updates.

Alongside some of the bigger updates and changes, we‚Äôve focused on the small things, and rolled out a handful of updates that all add up to an easier, more delightful Cloud experience. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs new in Cloud.

Seamless transition from your browser to the Mac app

We want to make the transition between collaborating in Cloud and creating incredible work in the Mac app as seamless as possible. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve made it easy to see all your Cloud documents right from the Documents window on the Mac app. With this update, we‚Äôve flipped things around and made it easier to open documents in the Mac app right from Cloud in your web browser.

Opening documents in the Mac app from Cloud is easy. Simply click the Open in Sketch button at the bottom of the sidebar in any document‚Äôs overview.

You‚Äôll also find the Open in Sketch option by hovering over any document‚Äôs thumbnail in the main documents view and clicking on the ‚Ä¶ button.

Or, if you‚Äôre in a single Artboard, you‚Äôll see a new icon to the right of the zoom controls to open your document focused on that Artboard in the Mac app.

Better control of your version history

With Cloud, you get a full version history of your documents that you can easily review and even roll back to, at any time. When you hit Save on a Cloud doc, you‚Äôll create a new version, adding to the timeline in the sidebar you‚Äôll see when you view that document in your web browser.

That said, when you‚Äôve been working on a project for a while, that number of versions can become pretty big. Not every version is helpful to have around ‚Äì‚Äì especially older iterations of ideas you don‚Äôt want anyone else to accidentally end up using or referring to.

With that in mind, we‚Äôve added the option to delete versions of your Cloud Documents. All you need to do is open your document in the browser, hover over the version you want to delete in the sidebar, click ‚Ä¶ and choose Delete Version.

A safety net for deleted documents

Not had your morning coffee? Accidentally deleted that Library document your team all rely on? We‚Äôve all been there. And don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôve got your back!

We‚Äôve recently introduced a new Trash feature to Cloud. Now, rather than deleting your documents permanently right away, you‚Äôll send them to the Trash.

To restore any document in Trash, all you‚Äôll need to do is click on the document‚Äôs preview and choose Restore. You can also hover over the document‚Äôs preview in the Trash, click ‚Ä¶ and select Restore document.

Documents will stay in the trash for up to 90 days. After that we‚Äôll automatically delete them permanently. For more on deleting and restoring documents, read our documentation.

Support for Color Variables in Cloud Inspector

In version 69 of the Mac app, we introduced Color Variables. Now, Cloud Inspector supports them as well, making it incredibly simple for anyone to copy the color value and variable name for any Color Variable in their document, in whatever format they might need it ‚Äì‚Äì making developer handoff a breeze. To copy a Color Variable‚Äôs name and hex value to your clipboard, all you have to do is hover over it and click the copy icon that appears next to it.

Need a specific format like Obj-C or Swift? That‚Äôs easy as well. Just click on the name of that Color Variable and hover over the value that appears. From there, click on the arrow that appears to change to your desired format, and click the Copy icon.

More organized conversations

When you‚Äôre discussing the finer points of a design, conversations can move quickly, making it difficult to keep track of specific discussions and details ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôre all chatting in single stream of comments.

Previously, we introduced mentions to specifically call out a person and send them a notification. Now, we‚Äôve (literally) taken it one level further with threads. Threads are great for keeping conversations organized. For example, you can start a thread to focus specifically on the shape of a button, while the conversation continues elsewhere about the color scheme or copy, making your activity feed easy to scan and find what you need.

To start a thread, click the reply link underneath it the comment you‚Äôd like to start one on, type your comment and press ‚åò+Enter to post it.

A better way to manage notifications

Along with threads, we also took the time to rethink the notifications you receive about new comments on Cloud documents. Previously, your notification options were limited to a document level. This can be helpful, but when you‚Äôre working on a large document with a lot of people, getting notifications for every comment can be overwhelming.

Now, you‚Äôll have the option to subscribe to notifications not just on the document level, but for specific threads and even Artboards (or groups of Artboards) as well. So, you‚Äôll be able to tune into the conversations you‚Äôre directly involved in, and cut out the noise whenever it makes sense.

To receive notifications for a specific Artboard, choose Follow this Artboard from the drop-down menu in the sidebar in a single Artboard view.

Notifications for specific threads works exactly the same. Click on the X Replies link a comment to see the Thread, then click on the Follow this Thread option in the drop-down menu.

For more on managing notifications in Cloud, make sure to read our documentation.

These updates are all live in Cloud right now, and we hope they make collaborating on designs even easier. We always appreciate your feedback, so if you run into any issues or have any questions, please get in touch. Oh, and make sure to stay tuned for some more exciting Cloud updates coming your way soon!

entry.title: Part of your world: Why we‚Äôre proud to build a truly native Mac app
entry.summary: From personalization and performance, to familiarity and flexibility ‚Äî there are plenty of reasons to love native apps
entry.content:
Ten years after the first release of Sketch, a lot has changed. The design tools space has grown. Our amazing community has, too. Even macOS itself has evolved. But one thing has remained the same: our love for developing a truly native Mac app.

Native apps bring so many benefits ‚Äî from personalization and performance to familiarity and flexibility. And while we‚Äôre always working hard to make Cloud an amazing space to collaborate, we still believe the Mac is the perfect place to let your ideas and imagination flourish.

In this post, we thought we‚Äôd highlight just a few of the benefits that come with native macOS apps.

It‚Äôs the things you see‚Ä¶

When you use a truly native app, you get all the benefits that come as standard with the platform ‚Äî and for macOS, there are plenty! You can work across multiple windows, or in multiple tabs. You can manage your own local files in Finder, and browse back through previous versions saved on your Mac‚Äôs built-in storage. Then there‚Äôs Time Machine, which helps you keep a full history of your local files in case you want to revert to a much older layout, grab an important Symbol you accidentally deleted months ago, or just keep a full backup of all your work from v1.0 to your finished file.

Then there are the built-in customization options. Want to tweak a shortcut for a tool you use regularly, or add a new shortcut entirely? Take advantage of macOS‚Äô custom keyboard shortcuts and create your own from System Preferences ‚Äî putting your favorite Sketch features at your fingertips. Plus, it‚Äôs easy to completely customize your toolbar with a Ctrl-click, just like you would in Finder or Mail. Learn the method once and it‚Äôs easy to put the tools you need the most easily within reach. When it comes to personalizing your app to suit your workflow and preferences, native apps have the controls you need.

We think the best way to design is in a truly native application, built beautifully ‚Äî and made for macOS.

Best of all, native Mac apps like ours are designed to fit with the rest of the operating system. It‚Äôs hard to quantify, but if you use Apple‚Äôs built-in apps you immediately get a ‚Äòfeel‚Äô for how things should work in native apps. When an app ‚Äòfits in‚Äô with the rest of the OS, it doesn‚Äôt just look and feel more at home on your Mac ‚Äî it lowers the learning curve when you first open it. That‚Äôs why we (and plenty of other great macOS developers) work hard to follow the conventions set out in Apple‚Äôs Human Interface Guidelines, so that our Mac app has that same, familiar feel. And you can start using it instantly, from the first click.

This is something we pride ourselves on ‚Äî over the years we‚Äôve taken design cues from Apple, working hard to make your experience feel consistent and natural whenever you switch from our Mac app to apps like Pages or Keynote. We support UI changes, such as Dark Mode, as they launch. And right now we‚Äôre putting the finishing touches to a major UI update so that our Mac app will still look perfectly at home when macOS Big Sur releases later this Fall.

‚Ä¶and the ones you don‚Äôt.

Of course, for all the obvious features that you can see and use every day, there are dozens more that help make native Mac apps better to use. You may not always know about them, but these behind-the-scenes benefits are one of the biggest reason we continue to champion a truly native app.

It starts with native macOS technologies. Building our app with the likes of Metal and Swift makes a big difference to things like rendering, performance and our memory footprint, too. And we‚Äôre continuing to improve things in both of these areas ‚Äî the updates we made with version 67 are one example.

Native Mac apps can offer a better user experience by building on top of Apple‚Äôs tried and tested frameworks, improving everything from battery life to accessibility.

As a native app, we can easily support OpenType font features and P3 color profiles (because Apple does), so your designs look their best. Plus, our Mac app works with OS extensions and actions, like the ability to look up words or search with Google with a Ctrl-click ‚Äî without needing any workarounds.

Plus, one of the biggest benefits is the option to use your native apps anywhere ‚Äî even when you don‚Äôt have an internet connection. We‚Äôll still need you to go online to confirm your license, but once that check is complete you can jump onto a long-haul flight, hike up a mountain or just switch off Wi-Fi on your Mac and keep designing in Sketch until long after the sun goes down.

This isn‚Äôt just about us, though. Every native Mac app can offer a better user experience by building on top of Apple‚Äôs tried and tested frameworks, giving you everything from better performance and improved battery life to world-class accessibility.

It all comes down to choice.

For us, the ultimate benefit of being a native macOS app is that it puts the choice in your hands. Like we said above, we‚Äôre always working hard to make Cloud a great place to collaborate, but if you need to work locally in a native application on your own Mac, you always have the option. And if you prefer to store your design files on your Mac‚Äôs hard drive, a shared file server or an enterprise Box setup, you can.

The same goes for backups. Of course we‚Äôll keep your files safe and secure if you store them in Cloud, but you can always keep a local version too, if you want. Want to stay in control of which version of Sketch you‚Äôre working with? We get it, sometimes you don‚Äôt want to update your tools close to a deadline ‚Äî we do the same with Xcode ;-). Just stick with your current version until you‚Äôre ready to update. The moment you‚Äôre ready, you‚Äôll get all the performance improvements and latest features (like Color Variables and real-time collaboration ‚Äî which is coming soon) that each new release brings.

We want to give you the best of all worlds. The latest features delivered directly to a native Mac app, with all the functional benefits that brings. The ability to choose how and where you work. The option to share your work and handoff to others in Cloud. And soon, the ability to collaborate in real-time.

Ultimately, the choice is in your hands. We want to give you the best of all worlds. The latest features in a native Mac app, with all the functional benefits that brings. The ability to choose how and where you work. The option to share your work and handoff to others in Cloud. And soon, the ability to collaborate in real-time.

We simply couldn‚Äôt do this without being a native Mac app. macOS is an amazing platform to work on, and we‚Äôre grateful to the community of designers like you that use Macs every day to create amazing work. Thank you for supporting us, and all the other native apps that help make the Mac the platform it is today. And thank you, Apple, for giving us a place to call home.

entry.title: From one to one million: how we grew Sketch around our incredible community
entry.summary: To celebrate our tenth anniversary, we chatted to some of the Sketch team about how we grew to reach an amazing milestone
entry.content:
‚ÄúTen years ago there wasn‚Äôt a tool that defined standards when it comes to designing user interfaces,‚Äù explains Sketch‚Äôs co-founder and Chief Design Officer, Emanuel S√°. ‚ÄúWe wanted a way to explain to people that interface design is not an afterthought. It is part of a huge process ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not a small part. It needs to be well-done and understood by everyone involved. And most importantly it needs to be useable by everyone in the team. That was the goal with Sketch.‚Äù

Back in 2010, the design landscape looked very different. Skeuomorphism was the hot trend. Sharing platforms like Dribbble and Instagram didn‚Äôt exist yet. And design software simply wasn‚Äôt as accessible as it is today.

‚ÄúWe wanted a way to explain to people that interface design is not an afterthought. It is part of a huge process ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not a small part. That was the goal with Sketch.‚Äù

A lot has changed since then. Now, with over one million customers, Sketch has become the go-to for designers and teams around the world. So we thought we‚Äôd talk to some of the people who‚Äôve been involved from our earliest days to find out how we got to where we are today.

The early days

‚ÄúThe first versions of Sketch were built highly collaboratively,‚Äú says Pieter Omvlee, Sketch‚Äôs co-founder and CEO. ‚ÄùAt first it was just Emanuel and me on design and development, but the lines were always blurry; we collaborated heavily and never had one side dictate what the other should do. As we‚Äôve grown the team I think we‚Äôve managed to keep that spirit. People with different expertise should work together and contribute so that we get to the best result.‚Äù

As people began to pick up on this approach and started using the Mac app, a community began to form. And this is where the success of Sketch really started. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask me how that happened, I have no clue,‚Äù laughs Emanuel. ‚ÄúPeople just really loved it. I think the price, the technology, the freedom ‚Äî it allowed a lot more people to look at design as real career. The right tool was available on the right platform. And we were so lucky to have a lot of people who kept pumping in resources; icon sets, interface sets, plugins and more.‚Äù

Forming a Community

‚ÄúThe community has played a monumental role in shaping the design space and the tools we all work with,‚Äù says Galya Iliev, who started her Sketch journey in that community, before joining the company in 2015. She‚Äôs now our Head of Partnership Marketing and Commercial Opportunities, working closely with the community every day. ‚ÄúDesigners loved the native feel of an app made specifically for UI and UX design.‚Äù As creatives began to use it in their day-to-day work, they shared their designs and thoughts on social media. Tutorials appeared on YouTube and designers started meeting up to talk about Sketch in more detail. It was incredible to watch, and the team were blown away by the support.

‚ÄúWe were so lucky to have a lot of people who kept pumping in resources; icon sets, interface sets, plugins and more.‚Äù

‚ÄúI remember some of the first Sketch meetups in San Francisco, Paris, Mexico City, and Beijing ‚Äî to name a few!‚Äù says Galya. ‚ÄúOur team members began to travel and attend events and had some amazing conversations with community members that sparked internal chats and, in some cases, great new feature releases.‚Äù

These conversations gave the team valuable feedback that they could use to make the app better for everyone. And when it didn‚Äôt make complete sense for them to dedicate time to developing a feature, the community stepped up ‚Äî developing amazing extensions and integrations to cater to those specific needs. ‚ÄúWhen creating a tool like Sketch, you can easily get distracted with an infinite amount of potential features to add,‚Äù explains Ale Mu√±oz, our Developer Relations Manager (and a long-time plugin developer himself). ‚ÄùTo keep a laser-focus, it‚Äôs essential to say ‚Äòno‚Äô to many of those ideas. Extensions can cover the proverbial last mile of design workflows, while we concentrate on making Sketch a great tool for everyone.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe community has played a monumental role in shaping the design space and the tools we all work with. Designers loved the native feel of an app made specifically for UI and UX design.‚Äù

While Ale is right, tracking feedback and suggestions from the people that use our Mac app every day is still an essential part of our workflow ‚Äî and it helps us make Sketch better. ‚ÄúCustomer feedback is a core part of how we think and evolve our product,‚Äù says Diana Ribeiro, our Customer Success Manager. ‚ÄúIt sits at the center of everything we do and ripples across every department at Sketch. I feel really fortunate to have such a passionate and vocal user base, and it‚Äôs very important to us that our customers feel heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think our success stems from knowing when to add features people are asking for, when to add features they‚Äôve never thought of, and when to to refuse to add features that don‚Äôt make sense,‚Äù adds Pieter.

Developing an ecosystem

As Ale explains, though, that decision isn‚Äôt always easy. Sometimes, feature requests are sometimes a signal that we should be doing something better. ‚ÄúThat creates a new set of challenges for us. We want to offer our customers the best tools, but we never want to alienate the developer community by ‚ÄòSherlocking‚Äô successful plugins,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe try not to base our work on existing implementations, but sometimes it‚Äôs inevitable to come up with similar solutions. There are only so many ways to do some things.‚Äù

Ultimately, though, it comes down to making sure everyone has exactly what they need to create their best work in Sketch ‚Äî whether we build it or it comes from our amazing plugin community. ‚ÄúOne of my most common answers when people ask me ‚Äòdoes Sketch do this thing?‚Äô is ‚Äòno, but there‚Äôs a plugin for that‚Äô,‚Äù Ale smiles.

One reason for this wealth of plugins is the early decision to make Sketch‚Äòs file format open. The team has always believed that your files are your own, and you should be able to do whatever you want with them ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs writing dev tools, or using them in another app. That decision has given our fantastic community of designers and developers scope to help shape the platform ‚Äî with their knowledge, as well as their extensions.

‚ÄúSketch‚Äôs plugin architecture offered literally unlimited possibilities for developers,‚Äù Ale continues. ‚ÄúBack then, there wasn‚Äôt a lot of information available for plugin developers. So a very passionate, closely knit group of hackers gathered around small pools of knowledge like the Sketch-plugins mailing list. I remember being amazed by the work other plugin devs shared there.‚Äù

‚ÄúBack then, there wasn‚Äôt a lot of information available for plugin developers. So a very passionate, closely knit group of hackers gathered around small pools of knowledge like the Sketch-plugins mailing list.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe knowledge sharing has been so humbling to watch,‚Äù says Galya. ‚ÄúDesigners from every walk of life ‚Äî from individual designers to bigger product teams at Google, Facebook, Apple, and IBM ‚Äî all created resources and integrations with Sketch. And when there‚Äòs that kind of great synergy, there‚Äôs also a lot of collaboration.‚Äù

From our perspective, it‚Äôs incredibly uplifting to see close-knit communities form around the world with a passion for great design at their core. It‚Äôs been incredible to see how our app has helped forge relationships and friendships around the globe.

It all comes down to you

And so, in 2019, almost by accident, Sketch passed one million customers. ‚ÄúIt passed by without us noticing,‚Äù smiles Pieter. ‚ÄúIt was only looking back that we realized. It‚Äôs really not a milestone we were striving for or working towards. The goal has always been to build a better product and hope, or trust, that the rest would take care of itself.‚Äù

But of course there are big benefits to having such a large, active and experienced community. ‚ÄúOver the years, I have witnessed a massive shift in how we relate and interact with our customers,‚Äù says Diana. ‚ÄúLooking back, our customer base isn‚Äôt just bigger ‚Äî it‚Äôs matured, too. And that‚Äôs pushed us to refine and improve.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an amazing feeling to see people with such diverse backgrounds and in so many different places use our product to build what they‚Äôre passionate about.‚Äù

Diana‚Äòs sentiment applies across every part of Sketch. We‚Äôve grown along with you ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre an individual designer or part of a larger team. And as we ask Emanuel to reflect on ten years of Sketch, the gratitude he feels is clear. ‚ÄúI feel honored and forever humble,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a privilege to be able to work for this community.‚Äù

Pieter shares that feeling. ‚ÄúWe could have never imagined it,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe built Sketch because Emanuel needed it and we figured there‚Äôd be more people like him out there. It took off in a bigger way than we could have ever dreamt.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an amazing feeling to see people with such diverse backgrounds and in so many different places use our product to build what they‚Äôre passionate about.‚Äù

This is our second post celebrating ten years of Sketch. Take a look at our interview with Emanuel to hear his thoughts on the last ten years in design, and keep an eye out for more stories from 2010 in the coming months.

entry.title: How to make the most of Color Variables
entry.summary: Learn how to easily sync and manage colors across your designs ‚Äî and update your existing documents to take advantage of this new Component type
entry.content:
Whether you‚Äôre working on a single webpage or an entire design system, the colors you choose have a huge impact ‚Äî from usability and accessibility, to brand identity and character. With version 69 of the Mac app, we introduced Color Variables ‚Äî a new component type that makes it easy to sync and manage colors across your designs.

In this post, we thought we‚Äôd share some tips and tricks to help you make the most of Color Variables, as well as some advice on how to adopt them in existing and older documents.

If you‚Äôre reading about Color Variables for the first time, don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôll kick off with a quick recap. You can also find out more about them in our documentation.

Updating colors in your design with Color Variables

Any changes you make to a Color Variable will automatically update across all the layers that use it. The same goes for Color Variables in Libraries. Any changes you make to them will appear as an update for all the documents that use it, too.

You can read more about how to create and edit Color Variables in our documentation.

Organizing your Color Variables

Keeping your Color Variables organized makes editing them a breeze and inserting them with Insert Window even faster. You can use the Components View to rename, group and edit them.

Find out more about the Components View and the Insert Window in our documentation.

Top tip: When you‚Äôre starting a new document, instead of choosing placeholder colors at random, why not create them as Color Variables and apply them to all the layers that need them? That way, you can tweak that ‚Äúinactive grey‚Äù until it‚Äôs just right and be sure every layer gets the update.

Moving over from Color Presets

Before Color Variables, you could store colors as Global or Document presets. Document presets were exclusive to a specific document. On the other hand, Global presets were available to any document you opened in your copy of the Mac app. However, any edits you made to presets would not sync up across your design.

When you update to version 69, we‚Äôll migrate your Global presets into Color Variables and create a Library for them. We‚Äôll also number them so they stay in the same order they were as presets. You can edit or rename your migrated Global presets by heading to the Libraries tab in Preferences and double-clicking to open the ‚ÄúMigrated Global Colors‚Äù Library. Then, head to the Colors tab in the Components View and make your changes.

As for Document colors, you will now find them as Color Variables within the document. Any gradient and image fills will still appear as Document or Global presets.

Working with Layer Styles and Color Variables

Even though Color Variables and Layer Styles are two different types of Components, they can work hand in hand to make your life easier. You can use Color Variables to keep colors in your styles consistent and make updates to all of them with a single change.

As a reminder, with Layer Styles, you can store a set of styles and reuse them across different shape layers within your designs. Updating a Layer Style will update every layer that uses it. They‚Äôre are a great way to keep elements of your design consistent.

If you have Layer Styles with properties that all use the same color, applying a Color Variable to them will making it easier to update that color across every style at the same time. This is especially useful for larger or more complex design systems, where you might be using brand colors that need to stay consistent and updating those colors across tens or even hundreds of styles could take a long time.

The same approach also works with Text Styles. You might have lots of different styles set up for various heading sizes, body copy and alignments. Using Color Variables across all of them makes it far easier to keep colors consistent and apply updates fast.

For example, let‚Äôs say you have two Layer Styles and one Text Style:

  • Primary Style, which uses a blue fill
  • Secondary Style, which uses that same blue, but as a border
  • Secondary CTA, which uses the same blue as a text fill

If you create a Color Variable for that blue color and apply it across all the Layer and Text Styles, any change you make to that Color Variable will update across every Layer and Text Style that uses it automatically ‚Äî saving you time and making sure everything is consistent.

Working with Color Variables and Tints

Back in Sketch 64, we launched Tints ‚Äî an easy way to apply a solid color to a entire Symbol or group of layers. Tints are ideal for things like icons or iOS-style tab bars that combine an icon with a text label. By setting up Tint overrides for Symbols, you can change them fly for Symbol instances. And with Color Variables, you can take things a step further.

By setting up different Color Variables for different states, applying a single Color Variable to a Tint override becomes far easier than creating different Layer Style and Text Style overrides that you‚Äôll need to keep up to date and change whenever a specific state color changes.

Take a look at this iOS tab bar as an example. By grouping the icon and the label together, applying a Tint, and making it a Symbol, we can use different Color Variables as Tint overrides to show inactive and active states.

Migrating older documents to Color Variables

When it comes to adopting Color Variables with older documents and design systems, we‚Äôve tried to make this as easy as possible. We‚Äôve added Color Variables controls to the Find and Replace Color sheet and we‚Äôve built a plugin specifically to help make migration a breeze. Here‚Äôs how both can help.

Note: Presets that are now Color Variables won‚Äôt automatically apply to the Layers that used them, but don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôve created a plugin to help with this ‚Äî more on that later.

Color Variables Migrator

Our Color Variables Migrator plugin matches the color in a Style or Layer with a Color Variable, making it quick and easy to update Layer and Text Styles to use Color Variables. If you‚Äôre working with a large design systems with lots of Layer and Text Styles, this could save you a lot of time.

If you were using document presets, we‚Äôll automatically convert those into Color Variables so you can start using the plugin right away. If you were not using presets, you‚Äôll need to create the Color Variables you need first and then run the plugin.

Once you are ready, there are two options you can choose from ‚Äî you can pick one or both. The first option will update every layer with matching Color Variables in the document while the second one will update every Layer or Text Style.

Keep in mind that the plugin will only work in your current document so if you want to migrate shared Libraries, you‚Äôll need to open them first.

You can download the Color Variables Migrator from our Plugin directory.

Find and Replace Color

We‚Äôve updated the Find and Replace Color sheet to include Color Variables controls, making it easy to find colors and quickly replace them with Color Variables. It‚Äôs handy for quickly creating Color Variables from Layer Styles.

To get started, head to Edit > Find & Replace Color and select the color you want to replace in your document. Then, open the Color Popover next to ‚ÄúReplace with‚Äù and choose Create Color Variable to create a new one with the same values as the color you‚Äôre rplacing. Your new Color Variable will automatically update any Layer or Text Styles that use it.

You can use Find and Replace Color sheet to find similar colors in your design and replace them with a Color Variable. You can also use it to replace multiple opacities of the same color ‚Äî just keep in mind that when you replace them with a Color Variable, it won‚Äôt preserve those opacities. You can read more in our documentation.

We hope you‚Äôll enjoy using Color Variables in your designs. We‚Äôre always listening to your feedback, so if you have any questions or run into any issues, please get in touch and let us know.

entry.title: Color Variables, Components View and a new Insert Window ‚Äî what‚Äôs new in Sketch?
entry.summary: With our latest Mac app update, we‚Äôre excited to introduce three new features ‚Äî Color Variables, Components View, and a new Insert Window ‚Äî making Sketch an even better home for design systems.
entry.content:
With this latest Mac app update, we‚Äôre introducing three features that we think you‚Äôre going to love. First, Color Variables ‚Äî a long-requested feature and a foundational building block for any design system. Then, a new Components View ‚Äî a proper home for your document‚Äôs local Symbols, Text Styles, Layer Styles and Color Variables. Finally, a new Insert Window that makes finding and inserting Components easier than ever.

Color Variables

Whether you‚Äôre working on a one-off project, or managing a complex design system, keeping the colors you use consistent and up-to-date is important. And with Color Variables, we‚Äôve made that a lot easier. They work exactly how you‚Äôd expect them to ‚Äî you can apply them wherever you‚Äôd normally apply a solid color. And when you make a change to a Color Variable, you‚Äôll see that update reflected automatically across every layer that uses it.

You can create Color Variables right from the Color Popover. We‚Äôve also introduced a menu to help you quickly access and apply existing Color Variables. You can edit them either from the Color Popover or from the new Components View.

Color Variables replace solid color presets. When you open a document, we‚Äôll automatically convert any existing solid color presets in it. Any global solid color presets will become their own local Library, available for every document that used them. If you want to edit them, simply open the Library document from the Libraries preference panel, like you would with any other Library.

We‚Äôve had plenty of requests for something like Color Variables over the years ‚Äî and throughout development and testing we‚Äôve found them to be incredibly useful. We hope you will, too! For more information, take a look at the documentation. We‚Äôve also put together a short video to show you more and released a Color Variables Migrator plugin to help with adopting Color Variables in your older documents.

Components View (Beta)

Along with a whole new type of Component, this update also introduces a new home for them. The new Components View gives all of your document‚Äôs Symbols, Text Styles, Layer Styles and Color Variables the space they deserve.

Clicking on the Components View tab in the Toolbar will switch out the Canvas for a whole new view in your document‚Äôs window. There, you‚Äôll see a grid with a preview of every Component in your document. From there, we‚Äôve made it easy to organize them into groups, rename them, and even edit them in bulk using the controls in the Inspector. In other words, you no longer need to manually create a page full of text layers for the sole purposes of viewing and editing Text Styles.

This new Components View is all about organizing and editing Components that are local to your current document. Components from other Libraries are (by design) read-only, so you won‚Äôt see those here. To view and edit those, you‚Äôll need to open the Components View inside that Library‚Äôs Sketch document.

Conceptually, the Components View has been a long time coming and we couldn‚Äôt wait any longer to share it with you. With that in mind, we‚Äôre launching it in Beta and we‚Äôll bringing some additional improvements and polish to it over future updates. For now, though, you can take a video tour of the Components View or read the documentation.

Insert Window

The new Components View makes it easy to keep your Components organized. And we thought inserting them should be just as easy, too. Our Insert toolbar menu does a great job of that, and in this release we‚Äôve improved it with a search field that we previously introduced to the Symbol swapping and Overrides menus.

But we knew we could improve this workflow even more. So in this release, we‚Äôre introducing the Insert Window. As the name suggests, the Insert Window is a separate window, built specifically for browsing and inserting Components ‚Äî from your local document or any Library you have enabled.

We‚Äôve worked hard to make using this new Window fast. You can simply tap C on your keyboard to open it, type to search for what you need, filter between Component types, or browse through specific Libraries and groups in the sidebar.

When you find what you need, simply drag-and-drop it onto your Canvas. The window hides itself when you do this so you can see the entire Canvas, but you can also pin it to have it reappear automatically.

We‚Äôve also added a few nice drag-and-drop features ‚Äî like the ability to drop a Text Style onto a text layer to apply it, as well as Layer Styles and Color Variables with other layer types. You can even drag Color Variables onto Color Wells in the Inspector, and Symbols onto overrides.

For more information on the Insert Window, you can take a look at the documentation or watch our video.

More updates, improvements and fixes

Along with Color Variables, the Components View and Insert Window, version 69 of the Mac app also includes:

  • Smarter grids ‚Äî Re-ordering layers in grids, by dragging on their circular center handle, works in a more natural way. Layers will now shift around in way that avoids adding extra rows or columns.
  • A new name for Symbol masters ‚Äî As part of an industry-wide change with Figma and Adobe, we‚Äôve renamed Symbol masters. We now refer to a Symbol master as a Symbol Source.
  • Offset Path improvements ‚Äî We‚Äôve moved the Offset Path controls into the Inspector and now temporarily show you an outline of the original path to give you a sense of scale while you‚Äôre making adjustments.
  • Crash and bug fixes ‚Äî As always, we‚Äôve squashed some pesky bugs and fixed some unexpected crashes.

Version 69 of the Mac app is available right now and we hope you‚Äôll enjoy these latest updates. We always appreciate your feedback, so if you have questions or run into any issues, please get in touch. Meanwhile, keep an eye out for the next update which includes a nice UI refresh for macOS Big Sur. üòâ
